newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Jerusalem plan "declaration of war" - Palestinians.
newsitem.headline: Jerusalem plan "declaration of war" - Palestinians.

text.p: Palestinians on Friday condemned an Israeli decision to build a Jewish settler enclave in the heart of Arab East Jerusalem as a "declaration of war".

News of the decision by the Jerusalem municipality emerged late on Thursday, prompting Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to rush out a statement vowing to prevent the plan from going ahead now.

Israel's peace talks with Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organisation have been in crisis since March when Netanyahu broke ground on a Jewish settlement on a hilltop at the edge of Arab East Jerusalem.

Israel Television said the decision on Thursday granted a permit to Irving Moskowitz, a U.S. Jewish businessman who bankrolls Jewish settlement in occupied areas, to build for Jews in the 11,000-strong Arab neighbourhood of Ras al-Amoud.

"It's a known declaration of war on the Palestinians in East Jerusalem, on the Palestinians in general, and a complete disregard of the spirit of the signed agreement," Arafat's adviser Ahmed Tibi told Israeli army radio.
Saeb Erekat, Arafat's senior negotiator, said the Palestinian Authority had protested to Netanyahu's office insisting that the plan be scrapped.
"We have made great efforts to try to put the peace process back on track but Israel is insisting on destroying the peace process," Erekat told Reuters in Gaza.
Yossi Sarid, head of the leftist Meretz party in Israel's parliament, gave warning of a burst of violence over the project.

He likened the decision to Netanyahu's opening of a tourist tunnel entrance near Moslem holy sites in Jerusalem last September which sparked clashes and gun battles that took the lives of 61 Palestinians and 15 Israeli soldiers.

"I am really certain that the building in Ras al-Amoud is the match that will light the great fire in the territories, a great fire that will burn lives of both Jews and Arabs," Sarid, a former peace negotiator, told Israel Radio.

Israel's Jerusalem municipal planning commission gave conditional approval last December to a plan for 132 settler homes in Ras al-Amoud. The plan required the approval of Interior Minister Eli Suissa but was later shelved.

Jerusalem Mayor Ehud Olmert said the plan approved on Thursday was for a scaled-down project on the same land east of Jerusalem's walled Old City. Israel Television said this apparently did not require ministerial approval.
"We are fighting over Jerusalem here and one can imagine there are elements who don't like that," Olmert said.
Netanyahu's office voiced surprise at the decision.

"The prime minister heard late at night from the mayor of Jerusalem on the decision taken on the issue...the prime minister is working to prevent implementation of the plan," his office said in a hastily prepared statement.
In a later statement, Netanyahu's office said the prime minister opposed the start of construction "now", suggesting the timing was his biggest problem.
Miami-based Moskowitz is said to own the 3.5 acre (1.4 hectare) plot in Ras al-Amoud neighbourhood. The claim is disputed by Palestinian officials.
The status of East Jerusalem is one of the most volatile issues dividing Israelis and Palestinians. The PLO wants East Jerusalem as capital of a future Palestinian state.
Israel, which occupied East Jerusalem in the 1967 Middle East War, says both sides of the city form its "united and eternal" capital.
Palestinians say Israeli moves in East Jerusalem are aimed at pre-empting peace talks on the city's fate. There are now some 160,000 Jews in East Jerusalem and 155,000 Palestinians.
Olmert said he doubted Moskowitz would go ahead soon with the plan as approved because the American would fight to carry out the larger project.
